image.altText: A man sitting, looking at the camera

items.synopsis: Mustafa Chiahad's son was buried beneath the rubble of his parents' home in Talat N'Yaaqoub. The town, near the epicentre of Morocco's earthquake, has turned in to ground zero for destruction.

title.children: 'I don't have the words to describe it': Devastated families count cost of Morocco's quake

image.altText: junk food alongside healthy food

items.synopsis: The CSRIO report found construction workers had the poorest diets, while retirees and those in the fitness industry were the healthiest eaters.

title.children: Only one in five adults are eating enough veg, with alcohol and takeaway dominating diets, report finds

image.altText: Woman smiling leaning on fence

items.synopsis: A renter says her life was saved by a concerned property agent after mould began to engulf the walls of her former home.

title.children: Mould in Prudence's rental home could have killed her, but help came from a surprising place

image.altText: Text bubbles displaying common text scams overlaid over an image of a person on a laptop.

items.synopsis: The ATO says tax-related scams have almost doubled this year compared to last. Here's what to watch out for.

title.children: Tax return scams are on the rise — here's how to avoid 'giving away the keys to your house'

image.altText: Karen Andrews holds her hands up while sitting under a patio in her Queensland home

items.synopsis: Former Coalition cabinet minister Karen Andrews has revealed she endured sustained harassment inside the House of Representatives, with a male colleague regularly breathing heavily on the back of her neck.

title.children: Karen Andrews reveals male colleague used to breathe on her neck in Question Time

image.altText: Jimmy sits in his living room on his laptop.

items.synopsis: When a pattern emerged of people with brain injuries being scammed, a team in Melbourne designed a program to fight back.

title.children: Jimmy was romance scammed. Now he's helping to protect others like him

image.altText: A cowgirl wearing blue jeans and a pink shirt stands behind chutes a a rodeo

items.synopsis: Cowgirls from across the country have converged on outback Queensland for the nation's first female rodeo. Organisers say it's a huge leap toward creating pathways for passionate stockwomen in the male-dominated sport.

title.children: Usually cowgirls need to ride in the US to forge a career. An outback rodeo is changing that

image.altText: Composite of Indian man wearing a brown fleece jacket, an Indian couple in black and white, and an apartment building.

items.synopsis: For more than a decade, Kris Agrawal built a reputation as a reliable businessman. But the shocking collapse of his empire has left more than 150 mum and dad investors almost $60 million out of pocket.

title.children: The collapse of an $80 million property investment scheme

image.altText: An illustration of a pink egg in a blue nest with flying money notes with dollar signs on them

items.synopsis: As  the influence of superannuation funds – economically and politically — continues to grow, transparency over how member money gets used becomes crucial, writes Nassim Khadem.

title.children: With super assets set to top $9 trillion in 2041, should funds be more accountable about how they spend members' money?

image.altText: Convicted sex offender Peter John van de Wetering smiling in front of a grey wall

items.synopsis: Peter van de Wetering was sentenced to nine years in jail in 2016 for his attack on the 19-year-old backpacker.

title.children: 'It could happen again': Psychiatrists testify as Queensland backpacker rapist comes up for parole

image.altText: Soldiers attempt to tow a vehicle stuck in mud

items.synopsis: Harsh winter conditions will bring new challenges in the war in Ukraine. The fighting will not stop, but it will change its tempo — and both sides will face different tests, writes Mick Ryan.

title.children: Could the Marshall Mud be Putin's undoing?

image.altText: Kim Jong-un waves from a train

items.synopsis: Reports that Kim Jong Un is en route to Russia have drawn attention to the traditional method of travel for North Korean leaders — luxury, armoured trains that have long been a part of the dynasty's lore.

title.children: Kim Jong Un appears to have departed for Russia on his luxury armoured train

image.altText: Ocean scientist Dr Katy Soapi in profile on a boat with still water and the coastal edge of Suva behind her

items.synopsis: Meet the woman tracking ocean acidification in the Pacific — a rising danger that could destroy marine life and livelihoods.

title.children: 'We are definitely flying blind': Ocean acidification is a hidden threat in the Pacific

image.altText: A man of Asian appearance wears glasses and stands speaking at a podium in a room, in front of a chalkboard and computer screens

items.synopsis: Banned from Australia over an alleged foreign interference plot in New South Wales, Chen Hong maintains he has done nothing wrong and continues to criticise the diplomatic stance taken by the former Coalition government.

title.children: Chinese scholar barred from Australia takes part in high-level dialogue between nations in Beijing

image.altText: An aerial view shows the burnt remains of structures, next to a road heading down a hill towards a village

items.synopsis: With a seemingly endless supply of guns, money and young men willing to act as mercenaries, tribal fighting in PNG has become akin to guerilla warfare.

title.children: Hired gunmen, bush axe attacks and smuggled ammo: Why this PNG community turned on each other

image.altText: Greens party members Max Chandler-Mather and Adam Bandt at a press conference.

items.synopsis: The federal government's key housing policy is likely to pass parliament after an agreement was reached with the Greens.

title.children: Government's key housing policy set to pass parliament after deal with Greens

image.altText: Kylea Tink, Murray Watt, Yasmin Poole and Kevin Hogan on Monday night's Q+A.

items.synopsis: In the wake of her allegations an opposition MP yelled at and intimidated her, independent MP Kylea Tink says Australians had sent a message when electing the current parliament that they wanted to see politics done differently.

title.children: 'It's pretty dopey politics': Parliamentary behaviour comes under scrutiny on Q+A

image.altText: a woman with long hair sits on a long seat on a porch of a house

items.synopsis: Frustrated Richmond residents fearful of the impact of recent floods on the "forever chemicals" call on the Defence Department to expand its testing area beyond the military base.

title.children: Liana moved into her home six months ago. After getting a flyer in the mail, she won't drink the water

image.altText: A damaged van is seen on a road as a powerful storm hit Libya.

items.synopsis: Deadly storm winds and heavy floods have hit Libya over the past two days, with estimates of the number of people killed ranging from hundreds to thousands.

title.children: Thousands feared dead as storm floods Libya

image.altText: The Woolnorth wind farm visible from Robbins Island and an inset of an orange-bellied parrot.

items.synopsis: A company wanting to build a wind farm in the migratory path of the critically endangered orange-bellied parrot says climate change poses a greater risk to the species than birds colliding with its turbines.

title.children: Only 77 of these parrots are left in the wild. A wind farm developer says a few deaths is a risk worth taking

image.altText: A hand holding a $20 and $5 note with coins in front of a banana and coffee mug

items.synopsis: Feeding your family with the leftover cash in your wallet might be a thing of the past.

title.children: You'll be shocked by how much supermarket prices have gone up, but can you still feed your family for $10?

image.altText: A young Indigenous man in a cap, smiling.

items.synopsis: Steven Nixon-McKellar was 27 years old when he died following a police arrest in Toowoomba in 2021. A large crowd rallied outside the courthouse as the inquiry into his death began on Monday.

title.children: Demonstrators call for total chokehold ban as death in custody inquest begins

image.altText: A sign that reads Koumala State School with a fence and buildings behind it, blue sky, green trees.

items.synopsis: Donny Morrison, 69, died after being bitten by a snake he was uncoiling from a friend's leg at a school centenary celebrations.

title.children: Family thanks community who helped  grandfather after 'confronting' fatal eastern brown snake bite

image.altText: A woman voting at night at a cardboard polling booth

items.synopsis: The governor-general issues the writ for the Voice to Parliament referendum, setting in motion the timeline for the nationwide vote.

title.children: Australians have until Monday to enrol for Voice to Parliament referendum, as postal votes open

image.altText: A man with a moustache and nose ring wearing a hat leans against a tree trunk.

items.synopsis: As Australians prepare to vote in a historic referendum, the ABC's Voice correspondent Dan Bourchier travels to the north, west and east of the country for Four Corners and finds a nation grappling with its future.

title.children: Ben was going to vote Yes to the Voice. Now he's a hard No

image.altText: premier gesturing as she speaks, behind a lecturn

items.synopsis: Cabinet members have had to defend the premier's leadership from chatter about dissatisfaction among Labor colleagues.

title.children: Queensland Premier 'absolutely determined' to lead Labor after rumours of dissatisfaction in party ranks

image.altText: The silhouette of a man vaping.

items.synopsis: A study of more than 4,000 teenagers has found one in four have vaped, with researchers warning they are doing it in the mistaken belief it helps with stress and anxiety.

title.children: Not sure if your teenager is vaping? The latest statistics may shock you about Australia's fast-growing fad

image.altText: A woman singing into a microphone and gesturing in pink sparkly outfit.

items.synopsis: International K-pop star Lisa Manobal has come under fire from some Chinese fans on social media after it was announced the Blackpink singer would dance at the Crazy Horse cabaret club in Paris.

title.children: K-pop star faces social media onslaught from Chinese fans over performance venue

image.altText: Woman in cream outfit sits in desk, with a new flash behind her.

items.synopsis: The actor claimed the return of the show "is bigger than just me" as striking writers plan to picket the return of the show's fourth season.

title.children: 'I own this choice': Drew Barrymore brings back talk show amid Hollywood strikes

image.altText: A man in a polo shirt and jeans walks next to a man in a suit, leaving a brick building

items.synopsis: A Dutch court sentences Khalid Latif to 12 years in prison.

title.children: Former Pakistani cricketer sentenced in absentia for urging people to kill Dutch anti-Islam politician

image.altText: A middle-aged man with short, greying hair, dressed in a suit for a corporate-style headshot.

items.synopsis: Stephen Wells says he intends to do his "duty in representing the local community" if he is elected to Busselton council, but others say they are horrified by remarks he made about hiding his true views from voters.

title.children: 'Racist, sexist' council candidate insists he is a Christian, 'not a national socialist'

image.altText: An Indigenous boy, slightly smiling, looks at camera, neck-long curly hair, slight moustache and beard.

items.synopsis: Markyia Major, 17, from Yarrabah, near Cairns, has not had any contact with family for a month or accessed his bank account.

title.children: Police launch a major investigation into teen's disappearance as fears for his safety grow
